Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Assessing Tourniquet Application Proficiency Post-B-Con Training

Participants.evidence: A volunteer sample of 102 laypeople who completed the American College of Surgeons Bleeding Control Basic (B-Con) training was assessed.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised using permutated blocks to apply five different tourniquet types.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was correct tourniquet application, defined as applied pressure of ≥250 mm Hg within 2 minutes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using permutated blocks

Blinding.evidence: This nonblinded, crossover, sequential randomised clinical trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: conducted at Gillette Stadium and the Longwood Medical Area in Boston, Massachusetts, from April 4, 2018, to October 9, 2018. A volunteer sample of 102 laypeople

Result_Outcome.evidence: Participants correctly applied the Combat Application Tourniquet (CAT) at a significantly higher rate (92.2%) compared to other commercial tourniquets
